awd_titl_txt: Predictive Modeling of Multi-Solute Adsorption Equilibrium based on Adsorbed Solution Theories
awd_abstract_narration:
The occurrence of organic contaminants (OCs) in the environment is one of the greatest environmental challenges facing the Nation. Different remedial techniques are used to cost-effectively remove OCs from contaminated water. However, little is known about the adsorption properties and methods of these techniques over a broad range of solution conditions. These knowledge gaps limit our ability to design adsorption systems to remove these pollutants, as it is time-consuming and difficult to experimentally obtain data for the vast number of OCs in drinking water and wastewater. The objective of this research is to develop accurate predictive models that can predict adsorption of a wide range of OC mixtures. Removal of OCs from drinking water will directly protect human health, and removal of OCs from wastewater will protect the environment and enable water reuse. The research efforts will be coupled with an educational and outreach plan designed to: 1) broaden participation from underrepresented groups in research; 2) integrate the latest research findings with fundamental environmental concepts for broader dissemination to college students; and 3) train future engineers and increase awareness within communities about OCs.

The proposed research aims to develop predictive models for multisolute adsorption equilibria of a suite of OCs by two common adsorbents in either the absence or the presence of natural organic matter (NOM). The adsorption isotherms of multisolute mixtures of 2-6 aromatic solutes will be obtained for two representative adsorbents in the presence or absence of six representative NOM mixtures. The isotherm data will be used to model adsorbed phase activity coefficients of bisolute mixtures to establish poly-parameter linear free energy relationships (pp-LFERs) for the activity coefficients at infinite dilution. Next, predictive models for multisolute adsorption will be developed based on a combination of pp-LFERs and Real Adsorbed Solution Theory. Finally, NOM will be treated as one or two equivalent background compounds, and predictive models for multisolute adsorption in the presence of the six NOMs mixtures will be established. This new predictive modeling approach will give environmental engineers a tool to study multisolute adsorption more easily and overcome the limits of studying single-solute adsorption or ideal mixtures without consideration of solute interactions. Developing predictive models for multisolute adsorption contributes to a major advance in the application of adsorption to OC removal. In addition, multiple approaches will be employed in the educational and outreach plan, including involving underrepresented graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in research, integrating project findings into the environmental curriculum at Case Western Reserve University, and broadly disseminating findings to communities with diverse backgrounds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this study, we have developed predictive models for the multisolute adsorption equilibria of numerous organic contaminants (OCs) onto two prevalent adsorbents, namely granular activated carbon and resin. The ubiquitous presence of a diverse range of OCs in water systems poses a significant environmental challenge. Adsorption, particularly using materials like granular activated carbon and resin, is a frequently employed technology to remove OCs from water. However, designing an efficient adsorber necessitates reliable data on how these contaminants adhere in mixtures. Given the extensive variety of OC mixtures present in drinking water, industrial and municipal wastewater, groundwater, and reused water, acquiring experimental equilibrium data for all combinations is laborious. Our developed models offer a more efficient means of predicting these intricate adsorption equilibria.

Intellectual Merit

As far as we know, our study is the first to create detailed predictive models for how various contaminants adsorb to adsorbents. We did this by combining lab experiments, theories, and AI/machine learning modeling. With so many different contaminant mixtures out there, it might seem impossible to accurately predict how they'll adsorb to materials. You might think we'd have to keep studying one contaminant at a time forever before we can even start figuring out mixtures. But guess what? Our research came up with a new way of predicting how multiple contaminants can be removed by adsorption.

Our significant discoveries encompass the development of several AI/machine learning models designed to predict adsorption in diverse applications, including:

  1. Predicting the adsorption of hundreds of distinct organic compounds in water onto widely used materials such as biochars, carbon nanotubes, granular activated carbons, and resins.
  2. Forecasting the adsorption of chemical mixtures onto two commercial resins, employing both traditional adsorption theories and advanced machine learning techniques.
  3. Modeling the adsorption of hundreds of organic compounds onto soils across the globe, considering various environmental conditions.
  4. Creating models to estimate the removal of greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane through adsorption onto granular activated carbon.

Broader Impacts

The development of predictive models for multi-solute adsorption equilibria signifies a crucial advancement in the design of adsorbers for water and gas treatment. This holds particular significance for addressing the removal of mixed OCs, especially considering their co-presence at low concentrations. The direct impact extends to human health through OC removal from drinking water, while treated wastewater safeguards receiving waters from contamination and supports increased water reuse. The established predictive modeling approach provides environmental engineers with a valuable tool for more accessible exploration of mixture adsorption processes, elevating the field to unprecedented levels of sophistication.

Furthermore, this research underscores the effective application of innovative AI/machine learning tools in addressing environmental challenges. Adsorbents, integral to liquid and gas-phase separation and purification processes, stand to benefit significantly from the insights derived in this project, advancing their applications.

Lastly, the profound influence of adsorption on soils and sediments in governing the fate and transport of diverse contaminants in the environment is addressed. Our established modeling approaches empower comprehensive studies of mixture adsorption processes, offering invaluable insights for inclusion in environmental fate simulators geared towards risk assessment and site cleanup.

This initiative has provided training opportunities for five Ph.D. students, seven undergraduate students, and one high school student. Our findings have been disseminated through presentations at various professional gatherings, institutions, and peer-reviewed publications. Furthermore, we have organized outreach activities, including workshops for students from preK to 12th grade, an easily accessible online calculator for the public to explore our machine learning models, local workshops focusing on emerging contaminants and climate action planning, as well as providing career counseling for both undergraduate and graduate students. Additionally, we have contributed ideas for four college senior design projects. These endeavors are designed to enhance awareness and foster interest in engineering advancements, ultimately contributing to a more comprehensive understanding of these innovations.
